content: In 2008 I graduated from Ryerson University with a degree in New Media. The program focused on concepts connected with emerging technologies and taught practical applications of HTML/CSS, as well as circuit building, and graphical programs like After Effects.
My final New Media project was a trucking theme game styled after early graphical adventure games. The project was featured in Ryerson's Nuit Blanche showcase of 2007.

My first role in the tech industry was with Webkinz in 2008 (a division of Ganz Studios), at the time a leader in the world of online family entertainment, which gave me an invaluable foundation for working in tech: Participating in Scrums; using a version controlled repository; coordinating with multiple departments (Creative writers, devs, QA, and artists) to produce interactive content; adhering to strict technical standards when delivering assets. At the time, I was coding in ActionScript, the programming language of Flash.
My next full time role was with ELL Technologies, an english language software producer, which provided the chance to contribute in the world of education design.

My role at marketing agency Inter-Web was a fast-paced role in which I took a central role in designing, prototyping and writing  spec documents for several eCommerce websites. I created art concepts and wrote HTML/CSS to launch landing pages and e-newsletters. It was largely the positive experiences coding for web which led me to embark on a career based on working with front-end technology.
In my spare time, I enjoy digging up facts and personal accounts about the history of computer technology, software and games. I'm an avid reader and tea drinker, as well a frequent badminton player.
I volunteer with an organization called Destination Imagination, which facilitates extracurricular creative and engineering challenges for children and high-school students.
